definition:
A **(right) pre-Hilbert module** over a $C^*$-algebra $A$ is a right
$A$-module ${\mathord{\mathcal{E}}}$ equipped with an $A$-valued inner
product
$\langle-,-\rangle\colon {\mathord{\mathcal{E}}}\times {\mathord{\mathcal{E}}}\to A$,
i.e. a sesquilinear pairing satisfying $$\begin{aligned}
\langle u,va\rangle & = & \langle u,v\rangle a \\
\langle u,v\rangle & = & \langle v,u\rangle^* \\
\langle v,v\rangle & \geq & 0, \mbox{ with\ } \langle v,v\rangle = 0 \mbox{ iff\ } v = 0,\end{aligned}$$
for all $u,v \in {\mathord{\mathcal{E}}}$ and $a \in A$. Note, positive
definiteness is well-defined due to the notion of positivity for
$C^*$-algebras. The norm of an element $v \in {\mathord{\mathcal{E}}}$
is defined by ${\Vert v\Vert} = \sqrt{{\Vert \langle v,v\rangle\Vert}}$.

A **(right) Hilbert module** over a $C^*$-algebra $A$ is a right
pre-Hilbert module over $A$ which is complete with respect to the norm.

A complex Hilbert space is a Hilbert ${\mathbb{C}}$-module.

A $C^*$-algebra $A$ is a Hilbert $A$-module with inner product
$\langle a,b\rangle = a^*b$.

A **Hilbert $A$-$B$-bimodule** is a (right) Hilbert module
${\mathord{\mathcal{E}}}$ over a $C^*$-algebra $B$ together with a
\*-homomorphism $\pi$ from a $C^*$-algebra $A$ to
${\mathop{\mathrm{End}}\nolimits}({\mathord{\mathcal{E}}})$.
